thread.title: The Shack Organic Wholefood Market and Cafe opens in Penrith
thread.title_full: The Shack Organic Wholefood Market and Cafe opens in Penrith | News Local

author: Isabell Petrinic
title: The Shack Organic Wholefood Market and Cafe opens in Penrith
text:
media_camera “I had an opportunity to go out to Coogee, or Penrith — my gut said Penrith,” The Shack owner Steve Ajami said. Picture: David Swift Penrith The Shack cafe branches west Isabell Petrinic, Penrith Press February 23, 2017 3:11pm New hot spots in Sydney’s west satisfy growing hunger for fine dining ‘Cinderella’ suburb on course to get fairytale finish Nutella waffle tower takes chocolate obsession to new heights
THE Shack already has cafes in Monterey, Newtown and Gymea and is now branching out west.
The Shack Organic Wholefood Market and Cafe officially opens its doors in the leafy suburb of Lemongrove this Saturday at 9am.
Owner Steve Ajami has totally transformed the old milk bar, adding timber fence palings, vertical plants, custom-made tables, and opening up the windows.
media_camera “We’re looking to get licensed eventually,” The Shack Penrith owner Steve Ajami said.
The new cafe offers balcony seating, outdoor street dining, inside dining, and a VIP function room for hire replete with disco lights.
There are also pet rabbits and chickens on site. All the artwork has been done by street artist Billie Jean Concepcion, the 2014 designer for legendary NYC rapper Slick Rick.
media_camera Menu items at The Shack. media_camera Menu items at The Shack.
“I’ve spent $400,000 just on the fitout,” Mr Ajami said, adding “I want to develop Penrith into a hot spot here.”
The Shack’s menu is founded on the principals of the paleo diet, veganism, pescaterianism, gluten free, allergen free and of course, organic, free range produce.
media_camera “I’ve given Penrith my best store,” The Shack owner Steve Ajami said. Picture: David Swift media_camera The Shack is next to the Lemongrove shopping strip, pictured, which is also on The Crescent.
Menu items include the Nepean River Breakfast.
“We’re always trying to revolutionise the food game,” Mr Ajami said.
He said he wants residents to see The Shack as “their local” which is why he’ll also have basics like newspapers, bread and milk for sale.
Saturday’s opening will include appearances by Penrith Panthers player Josh Mansour and former player and coach Phil “Gus” Gould.
The Edge Street Team will be broadcasting live from the cafe from 11am.
There will also be free facepainting and food tastings.
media_camera Penrith Panthers player Josh Mansour will be at The Shack for the opening. Picture: Mark Evans media_camera The Shack team believe dietary restrictions should not mean you need to be restricted by flavour or fun.
■ The Shack at 12 The Crescent, Penrith, will be open 5.30am-4pm Monday to Friday and 6am-5pm Saturday and Sunday.
■ Details: theshackmarketcafe.com.au
